title: How Much Energy Does Bitcoin Actually Consume?
author: Nic Carter
description: Today, Bitcoin consumes as much energy as a small country. This certainly sounds alarming — but the reality is a little more complicated. The author discusses several common misconceptions surrounding the Bitcoin sustainability debate, and ultimately argues that it’s up to the crypto community to acknowledge and address environmental concerns, work in good faith to reduce Bitcoin’s carbon footprint, and ultimately demonstrate that the societal value that Bitcoin provides is worth the resources needed to sustain it.

title: Three Myths about Bitcoin’s Energy Consumption
author: Dominik Stroukal

title: On Bitcoin's Energy Consumption: A Quantitative Approach to a Subjective Question
author: Galaxy Digital Mining

title: Natural gas venting: How Bitcoin solved a 160 year old problem
author: Steve Barbour
description: Vented natural gas is the controlled release of produced gas into the atmosphere. It typically comes out of solution with the produced oil but in many cases it is simply leakage from pipe, valves, tanks or instrumentation. Some facilities have infrequent, small releases while some sites release gas up to and beyond regulated limits. Natural gas release is a particularly bad carbon emitter because it is mostly made of methane, which has 25 - 30 times the global warming potential than carbon dioxide per unit mass.

title: Bitcoin Mining and the Case for More Energy
author: Hodl'n Caulfield, Selene Lindstrom

title: Addressing Persisting Bitcoin Criticisms
author: Ria Bhutoria
keywords: volatility, store-of-value, energy, illegal, competitor, not-backed-by-anything
description: In this piece, we review and respond to criticisms and misconceptions that continue to come up in our conversations. The criticisms outlined below have been addressed many times over, but we wanted to share an updated response given the increase in attention on Bitcoin.

title: Critique #4: Bitcoin Wastes Energy
description: Bitcoin's energy spend is required to do three things: fairly distribute new bitcoin according to bitcoin's monetary policy, allow anyone to participate in the bitcoin network on even footing, and create the strong security assurances around bitcoin's transaction settlement. Any financial system will have certain properties and guarantees, and they never come for free.

title: End the FUD

title: Estudio Bitcoin
description: A bit of everything to introduce you to the world of Bitcoin

title: Bitcoiner books

title: Libbitcoin
description: The libbitcoin toolkit is a set of cross platform C++ libraries for building bitcoin applications. There are also in this resource a lot of articles discussing Bitcoin from different points of view.

title: Every Reason Bitcoin Will Not Fail
description: Collection of articles explaining why Bitcoin will not fail

title: Getting started with Bitcoin
description: A collection of articles for getting started with Bitcoin, from the first steps to the misconceptions, and much more.

title: Why Bitcoin, The Series
author: Tomer Strolight
description: Bitcoin is a vast subject, with countless facets, angles and perspectives. It can be looked at, thought about and appreciated in many ways. By writing very short pieces I hope to take a single snapshot of Bitcoin from a different perspective with each one, so that the reader may upon finishing, better understand the whole.

title: Gradually, Then Suddenly
author: Parker Lewis
description: A series of articles of reference in the Bitcoin world
